  sylancr(wa(wbr(c0, clt, c2), wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, c1))), wrex(s0, cprime, wa(wbr(c0, clt, cv(s0)), wbr(cv(s0), cle, co(nat2, cmul, c0)))), wcel(c2, cprime), wa(wbr(c0, clt, c2), wbr(c2, cle, co(nat2, cmul, c0))))

thm bpos1lem(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, wff w0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` c1)→ w0)

  fsumle(hs0, co(nat1, cfz, co(nat2, cmul, c0)), co(cfv(cfl, co(co(nat2, cmul, c0), cdiv, co(c1, cexp, cv(hs0)))), cmin, co(nat2, cmul, cfv(cfl, co(c0, cdiv, co(c1, cexp, cv(hs0)))))), cif(nat1, nat0, wcel(cv(hs0), co(nat1, cfz, cfv(cfl, co(cfv(clog, co(nat2, cmul, c0)), cdiv, cfv(clog, c1)))))), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, cprime)))

blocks.name: bposlem2
blocks.content: There are no odd primes in the range ` ( 2 N / 3 , N ] ` dividing the ` N ` -th central binomial coefficient. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 12-Mar-2014.)

blocks.name: bposlem3
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ bpos . Since the binomial coefficient does not have any primes in the range ` ( 2 N / 3 , N ] ` or ` ( 2 N , +oo ) ` by ~ bposlem2 and ~ prmfac1 , respectively, and it does not have any in the range ` ( N , 2 N ] ` by hypothesis, the product of the primes up through ` 2 N / 3 ` must be sufficient to compose the whole binomial coefficient. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 13-Mar-2014.)

blocks.name: bposlem5
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ bpos . Bound the product of all small primes in the binomial coefficient. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 15-Mar-2014.) (Proof shortened by AV, 15-Sep-2021.)

blocks.name: bposlem6
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ bpos . By using the various bounds at our disposal, arrive at an inequality that is false for ` N ` large enough. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Mar-2014.) (Revised by Wolf Lammen, 12-Sep-2020.)

blocks.name: bposlem8
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ bpos . Evaluate ` F ( 6 4 ) ` and show it is less than ` log 2 ` . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Mar-2014.)

blocks.name: bpos
blocks.content: Bertrand's postulate: there is a prime between ` N ` and ` 2 N ` for every positive integer ` N ` . This proof follows Erdős's method, for the most part, but with some refinements due to Shigenori Tochiori to save us some calculations of large primes. See ~ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_of_Bertrand%27s_postulate for an overview of the proof strategy. This is Metamath 100 proof #98. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 14-Mar-2014.)
blocks.origin:

  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
} = {
  mpjaodan(wcel(c0, cn), wrex(s0, cprime, wa(wbr(c0, clt, cv(s0)), wbr(cv(s0), cle, co(nat2, cmul, c0)))), wbr(c0, cle, cdc(nat6, nat4)), wbr(cdc(nat6, nat4), clt, c0))
  bpos1(s0, c0)
  pm2.18da(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wbr(cdc(nat6, nat4), clt, c0)), wrex(s0, cprime, wa(wbr(c0, clt, cv(s0)), wbr(cv(s0), cle, co(nat2, cmul, c0)))))
  bposlem9(hs1, hs0, s0, cmpt(hs1, cn, co(co(co(cfv(csqrt, nat2), cmul, cfv(cmpt(hs0, crp, co(cfv(clog, cv(hs0)), cdiv, cv(hs0))), cfv(csqrt, cv(hs1)))), caddc, co(co(nat9, cdiv, nat4), cmul, cfv(cmpt(hs0, crp, co(cfv(clog, cv(hs0)), cdiv, cv(hs0))), co(cv(hs1), cdiv, nat2)))), caddc, co(cfv(clog, nat2), cdiv, cfv(csqrt, co(nat2, cmul, cv(hs1)))))), cmpt(hs0, crp, co(cfv(clog, cv(hs0)), cdiv, cv(hs0))), c0, wa(wa(wcel(c0, cn), wbr(cdc(nat6, nat4), clt, c0)), wn(wrex(s0, cprime, wa(wbr(c0, clt, cv(s0)), wbr(cv(s0), cle, co(nat2, cmul, c0)))))), wrex(s0, cprime, wa(wbr(c0, clt, cv(s0)), wbr(cv(s0), cle, co(nat2, cmul, c0)))))
